p: Fruits of S. incanum are found to be the source of several groups of phytochemicals, including terpenes, flavonoids, bioflavonoid, xanthenes, and multiple metabolites like tannins, saponins, cyanates, and oxalate, and anthraquinones [ 6] as well as steroid glycosides in the form of glycoalkaloids such as solanine and solasonine [ 7]. Likewise, the leaves of S. incanum L. are rich in minerals such as K [ 8] and Ca [ 9].
